Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 02:02AM delaine wrote: Hi Everyone Melinda-Tma... I see you are up late too. It is nearly 3am here and I just cannot get to sleep. I have just taken some ativan. Thanks for  letting me know what you did about the mouth care. The info. I have from the cancer centre said to try club soda but I also will use Biotene and the salt/baking soda combo. I really don't want mouth sores. I am going to start right away.  Yesterday was my first T/C and I still feel really well. We went out to an Indian restaurant for dinner tonight - I ate far too much. Revriki mentioned being bloated and I am bloated as well but not sure if it was the chemo or the overeating. Took the dog for a  3 km walk tonight so thought that might help me sleep but no luck there.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 11:18PM delaine wrote: Hi everyone krcll - I have always been a bit of a "low-energy" type (some might say lazy) so I feel about the same as always. I am having odd electric shock type feelings in my incisions every once in a while. It is a bit painful when it happens. Thanks for all the info. about the scarves; you have done a lot of work. London-Virginia  your post made me laugh out loud. I don't do that very much these days so thank you for that. The woman at the cancer accessory shop said the same thing about wearing larger, more dangly earrings with caps and scarves. I did buy three pair of new earrings on a recent trip but somehow I have misplaced them.   Good tip about drinking water and better veins. I had not heard that before.  ninjamom -do you have a port?
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 08:23PM delaine wrote: Hi all -started a long post but somehow it all disappeared.I am not very computer or forum-posting savvy. Jayne_in_UK - thanks for taking the time to wish us well and let us know that you are faring not too badly with your chemo. It is so helpful to hear. tamlyn110 - I had my bi-lat. mx on Aug. 6 - no recon. I had not heard the "iron bra" term before but that describes it perfectly. Are you doing the recommended exercises? (no, this is not a lecture). I went to a session at the hosp. yesterday where a physical therapist showed us how to do all the exercises correctly and we had to do them in front of her. Between that and wearing my mast. cami and fiberfills all day I was in agony by early evening. I did not take any pain meds at all for my surgery or since but I just had to last night. She stressed  that we do them twice daily. I have been doing a lot of walking but only doing the exercises off and on and only the easy ones - which sort of defeats the purpose. I don't know any details about my chemo. only that I will begin in Sept. I am scared too. Were you given the option of having a port? What a relief to be able to keep in touch with others going through the same things.  My husband was stung by a wasp yesterday and was nattering on about how painful it is. I just gave him the "look".   I think he got the message. Gitane - thanks for the info. on Emend, Kytril and Compazine.  I am keeping a notebook with those recommendations from those who have "been there and done that"
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2009 08:33PM delaine wrote: Hi - I am expecting to hear from the cancer clinic in about 3 weeks or so. I had my bi-lat max on Aug. 6/09. Saw my surgeon on the 14th. post-op . My ILC tumour was 4cm, SNB 0/4.My BS said that I will be having chemo and so I am probably going to start in September, as well. I have no other details yet. I, unlike, London-Virginia, am not looking forward to any of it. I just try to put one foot in front of the other and move on. London-Virg - your post did make me laugh though. krcll - thankyou for starting this thread (not sure if that is the correct term) as I will definitely need to have this kind of support and others with whom to compare notes. I live in Canada.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 07:23AM delaine wrote: Hi everyone mrsb45  We will be waiting to hear how you made out with your first treatment- I so hope it is easy for you.  Gitane - I take my pals where I can get em but your comment is  funny. I will head over to the ILC board tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 06:51PM delaine wrote: London-Virginia - I know what you mean - I tend to be outspoken and somewhat sarcastic (blunt, I've been told) but with this diagnosis my friends all say - you'll be just fine, you are so strong. I cannot believe they are talking about me. I am anxiety-ridden, weepy and afraid of the future. A real "dysmal Jimmy" as you put it.  Even my family thinks that the surgery was the biggest hurdle and that is over now. I think that was the easy part. Have you painted your finger and toe nails black? I will try that based on your success with it,    mrsb45 - how did make out today - was it easier than you expected? I hope so.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 04:15AM delaine wrote: Hi everyone London-Virginia and mrsb45 - you two are doing so well with all that walking and exercise and both of you feeling pretty good - love to hear that this is your experience so far. It is very reassuring to the rest of us who will follow you. Finally have a date for first consultation with an onc. on Sept. 10.  How do they decide who needs a port and who does not? I certainly don't want another surgery but could probably handle the "twilight sleep" that tammy had.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 12:14AM delaine wrote: Hi everyone Have not posted much on here since my first onc. consult is still looming - Sept. 10 for me. I do read the posts every day though. To those of you who have already started chemo, thanks so much for the updates. They are much appreciated. You all seem to be coping so well and with manageable side effects. I don't feel nearly as afraid as I did before, although not quite ready to toss the Ativan.  Virginia - love your posts - so informative and funny. The Korres products sound like something I would like. We don't have a shop in Canada but we do have Sephora in my city and maybe they carry them.  MN-Jeanne - how did it go today? Are you okay?
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 05:20PM delaine wrote: Hi everyone Day two for me - had first T/C yesterday mornng. Newtonville - it was so much easier than I anticipated. You'll do fine.I was fine, did a little shopping on the way home. Went for a 5 km walk later in the evening with my Dh and the dog.Still feeling quite well today, although I have learned from this site that the side effects might not kick in until day 4 but so far I feel quite well. I am still trying to drink a lot of water. Certainly has not affected my appetite in any way.  To the other who have gone before me did you start the mouth care rinses right away tyring to be proactive or do you wait until the need arises.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2009 06:20PM delaine wrote: Hi everyone Today is day 5 for me -had my first T/C this week. Last night the aches and pains started and kept me awake but up until then I have been feeling quite well. I do have  bloating but it seems to be less than it was. I am going to try Claritin today to see if that will help with the bone pain. Really feeling sad about losing my hair - although it has not started to come out yet - but I guess it is just one more hurdle to get through as was the surgery and the first chemo and we've all come through those and we're still standing.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 09:06PM delaine wrote: Hi everyone It was great to turn on computer today and see so many posts.  krcll - I try to do some of the exercises  in the shower - the warm water loosens things up a bit but I have not been as diligent as I should be. I never thought about only having a short period of time to get "stretched out" althought the physical therapist did stress how important it was to do them twice a day. I do not have a chemo start date - I have not talked to any oncs. I only know that the cancer centre will be calling me - 3 - 4 weeks post surgery - which was Aug. 6. I don't even know my HER2 status yet. Those electric shock feelings in my incisions make me flinch. We played bridge with friends last night and they must have wondered what I was doing - flinching away every so often. By the time we got home my body was in pain from having that cami and fibrefills pressing on me through the evening. I might try your idea of just pinning the fiberfills in to a looser cami - the mastectomy ones I have are a bit tight. Around the house I just go flat but too self-conscious to do that in front of anyone else. tamlyn110 -I, too, would like to know if you will be awake for the port. I had fears about the SNB and the mast. being scary and painful and they weren't painful at all - for me - so try not to worry too much about tomorrow's procedure (I know, easier said than done). Please let us know how you made out.  London-Virgina - what a good post. I think you are coping really well with all that walking and making nice meals for yourself. I try to walk 5km every day - not sure how close that is to 10,000 steps. I am too lazy to do more than that though.  I loved the description of your walk home - being in the middle of London, crossing the bridge and walking along the Thames. My trip home from the cancer centre will involve a car ride on the freeway back to the boring old "burbs". Not nearly as uplifting. I am so relieved to hear that you are not vomiting although being queasy is almost as bad. I think being weepy just comes with the territory. It is just so darn hard to cope with all of what we have to go through. It is like a physical and mental assault. The letter carrier said "have a nice day" to me the other day;  that sent me running for the tissues.    It sounds to me like you are handling it all really well - geting out and about. I am impressed. It gives us all hope. Ice lollies are popsicles - same thing. To those of us not living in the US - do you get oncotyp dx scores - I am not positive about it but I don't think they do that testing in Canada?   mrsb45 - how is it going today? Still feeling not too badly, I hope. Please update us when you can. Great to hear from MN-Jeanne, MarieK, unklezwifeonty, viday, Jayne_in_UK - keeping in touch through this site takes some of the "lonely" out of the treatment process.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 08:06PM delaine wrote: Hi Everyone Lots of good reading on this thread. We are such an internationally represented group - Can., Aus., UK, US, Norway. It is just great. Hope I did not miss anyone.  Finally had my onc. consulation this morning. I will be having TCx4. No radiation and the discussion about Tamox. or AI's will come later. Best of all, for my piece of mind, no port. I just could not get my head round that - or having another surgery to get it in. I hope I don't regret it.  Should be starting the week of Sept. 22 - they are to call me. I feel better just knowing that things are moving along and I can see and end to this. The ladies on these boards were so helpful and so right. You do feel better once you get a plan and you need to take one day at at time. I never thought I would be saying that when I first came here in June. It has been an overwhelmingly distressing situtation but each step was okay the bi-lat mast. was quite easy, no pain, good recovery. And I guess I will learn soon about chemo but we are all doing it together and that makes it so much easier. Virgiinia - I read that you might not be back here. Please say it isn't so. Your posts make me laugh so please stay. If not, then I wish that you would PM me anytime something strikes you funny - I need to be able to laugh through this.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2009 08:35PM delaine wrote: Hi Everyone London-Virg: Thanks for the welcome. I did understand what you meant by looking forward to chemo - as another step to getting all this over with. Your posts are funny; they make me laugh; we will need that for what is coming so please keep it up. DH and I were planning a trip to England this fall. Three of my grandparents were born there and one grandmother was born in Scotland. Maybe we will try it next fall.  I read as much as possible on the forums about chemo. I guess I had convinced myself that it will be pretty  bad but today I read some posts from women whose SE's were not that  difficult, so fingers crossed for all of us. I have already been to a shop that specializes in wigs and clothing for cancer patients. I have not made a final decision on a wig yet and was going to go with a one that looks just like my own hair but maybe I should look for something a little different. I really need to stop feeling so very sorry for myself and get on with things.  Ninjamom - I had bi-lat mx but with no reconstruction. It was pretty easy for me, really. I did not have to take any pain meds. I hope that your surgery will be just as easy as mine. I have come to this site every day, sometimes many times a day, since my dx and it has been such an enormous help to learn from the others here and to be able to share all aspects of having BC. I am particularly grateful to the women who have been through it all and still take the time to come back to encourage us and advise us.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 03:20AM delaine wrote: Hi newtonville I hear ya! I am frightened by the thought of chemo too. I was very much afraid of the surgery and that turned out to be not all that bad. So maybe the chemo won't be as terrible as we are imagining it to be. I guess we will find out soon enough but if we all keep in touch through this forum it will help - misery loves company, right?  The hair loss won't be fun but it will be winter and cold and we won't look out of the ordinary wearing our hats in public.I just really cannot picture me bald -I probably have a really weird looking head. This site is such a boon - cannot imagine how I would have coped this far without it.  krcll - just re-read your post and realized that you and I had surgery on the same day, Aug. 6. Every day gets easier for me, how about you?
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 02:14AM delaine wrote: mrsb45 Sorry to hear that you had a rotten migraine from the chemo. I hope that you are feeling better now, are you? London-Virginia - I am hoping that your treatment tomorrow will not be difficult. Keep us in the loop. How nice of your friends to actually volunteer to be vomited on. You have good friends. I'll be mentally putting my friends up against yours - I bet none of them are that loyal. Personally, I prefer to be sick in private so would not want them there anyway - just want to know how far they would go though. hello kcrll and newtonville - I have looked at the headcovers website - it is good to know that they ship their products so quickly.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 02:23AM delaine wrote: Hi all Hello to all the new posters on this thread. krcll - I hope you stay on this thead with us. You started it and we have become familiar with one another's stories. I am sorry that you have to deal with more surgery. It all stinks. victoriasecret - It looks as though you and I are the only ones on this thread with lobular cancer. Mine was 4cm, 0/4 nodes - don't know Her2status yet and no clue about what chemo I will get. My first onc. appt. is on Sept 10. I am in Canada too. I had bi-lat mx on Aug. 6 and the "iron bra" and electric shock feelings are starting to get on my last nerve. As well, I am doing the exercises (well most of them) and every morning when I get up it feels just as tight as it did the day before. I am walking 5 kms every day and when I get back from the walk I feel better but then the tightness comes back almost right away. London-Virginia - are you keeping up with the 10,000 steps.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2009 11:30AM delaine wrote: Hi everyone London-Virginia - I truly hope that you do not get chemo brain. I would not want anything to interfere with your sense of humour. That bit about chemo and sex made me laugh out loud.  I go for chemo orientation tomorrow morning. I am currently suffering with "port anxiety". Every day it is something else for me to obsess about but I really do not like the thought of a port or the surgery to have it placed.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 03:49PM delaine wrote: Hi everyone I have been reading all your posts and appreciate all the tips an updates. Tomorrow is my first chemo treatment. I just came back from my pre-chemo appt. with the onc. Have all my meds to take for the next three days. Funnily enough, no one at the clinic said anything about drinking a lot of fluid but I am going to do so. I am extremely apprehensive about tomorrow. I am getting T/C X 4.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 02:07PM delaine wrote: Hi Everyone  Had my first chemo this morning. It was so much easier than I had imagined it would be. My onc. had given me pre-chemo meds to take orally yesterday and today so that shortened the time I had to have the IV in my hand.  Did not get any allergic reaction to the Taxotere and no headache from the Cytoxan so they pushed it quite fast. Think I was in and out in about 3 hours.  The nurses were very efficient, pleasant and upbeat. The treatment room was bright, airy, spacious. We had DVD players if we wanted. The snack ladies came round often, so all in all, despite the crappy cancer which is why I was getting chemo - this part was not all that bad. When the side effects kick in and I am sick, tired and  bald I will be back to complaining and being a misery but today, so far, was just fine. I did drink a lot of water yesterday and during the IV infusion and will keep it up for the next few days. Thanks to all the incredibly strong women who post on this forum for sharing their experiences. It is so helpful to know how we are all coping. Cannot even imagine how much more lonely having cancer would be if this forum did not exist.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 03:04PM delaine wrote: Hi all, London-Viginia - I feel nervous right along with you. Your sense of humour and positive attitude will carry you along way. I am sure they would not give you chemo if your unhealed areas were going to be a problem but it is another rotten thing to have to deal with on top of everything else.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 01:14AM delaine wrote: Hi everyone Just reading all the posts. mrsb45 - I see that you are having a port inserted before your second treatment. I am curious - was it your choice or did your onc. recommend it. I go for my onc. consult on Sept. 10 - pretty sure I don't want a port but don't even know what chemo I will be getting. We saw the Jersey Boys while on holiday in Chicago last fall - absolutely loved it and I hope that you can go. It will make you smile.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 11:32AM delaine wrote: Had my post-op check today - had bi-lat mx on Aug. 6 along with SNB - 4 nodes removed. I have no incision in my arm pit. Mine seems to be farther down than what you ladies are describing. It does not hurt either. Someone please tell me that theirs is the same. I will be obsessing forever now that he was digging nodes out of the wrong spot.     My tumour turned out to be 4 cm which is larger than the mammo. showed. I have ILC, ER+PR+, 0/4 nodes, Grade 2 - nothing on the report about stage and my surg. did not mention it - and like the idiot I am, I  I did not ask. I think I am IIA from looking on-line.  There was nothing in the report about Her2 either.
Posts.Title: underarm discomfort after surgery marin MarieK

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2009 08:16PM delaine wrote: Hi Christine I chose a double with no recon. as well.My surgeon says recon is still an option if I want it but I don't think I will bother. I don't want to have any more surgery.  My range of motion is very good and my chest only feels tight in the mornings now. I just seem to have put my life on hold till my chemo is over and then I want to not have to think about cancer for a while - I hope that proves to be the case for all of us.  At home I just go flat most of the time and I am fine with that.
Posts.Title: Surgery on Oct 1st-- double masectomy, no reconstruction.. Christine2000 delaine

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 08:03PM delaine wrote: Hi I made the decision to have bi-la mx as soon as I was diagnosed. I have ILC - my breast developed a dimple - but no palpable lump. I knew that I would never have another moment of peace (probably won't anyway) worrying about whether it was sneakily growing in the other breast. My surgeon agreed with me. I had my surgery two days ago - still feeling a little shocky when I look down at my flat chest but I guess I will get used to it -don't have much choice anyway. As well, I think it will be easier to cope with dressing, etc to be assymetrical.Now have to get my head around dealing with what ever chemo they decide to give me. I am exhausted with this whole ordeal.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic bilateral mx simmonba CAROLMARIE427

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 05:20PM delaine wrote: Hi Positivity I, too, have a dimple in my right breast in the 9 o'clock position. There was no palpable lump and I had had an "all clear" mammo. 8 months prior. I stared at it and willed it to go away for three weeks before I finally made an appt. for diagnostic mammo. and ultrasound. Sure enough I have ILC and am having my mx surgery in two weeks time. They found it with the spot compression mammo. I did BSE every month and never felt any changes. I am in Canada too. The radiologist told me right then that I had cancer and to call my doctor - they did not make me wait for  a week for the test results. U/S guided biopsy confirmed it.  Hopefully yours will turn out to be nothing but you acted quickly and are being proactive.   I come to this forum all the time now because the women here are amazingly knowledgeable, empthatic and supportive.  You can get an MRI quickly if you go private. Cover all your bases. Keep us informed.
Posts.Title: Breast Dimpling Positivity Positivity
